title: HESI RN EXIT EXAM WITH NGN LATEST VERSION B 2024-2025

questions.stem: The nurse is completing the admission assessment of a 3-year old who is admitted with bacterial meningitis and hydrocephalus. Which assessment finding is evidence that the child is experiencing increased intracranial pressure (ICP)?
options: Tachycardia and tachypnea
Sluggish and unequal pupillary responses
Increased head circumference and bulging fontanels
Blood pressure fluctuations and syncope
questions.rationale: Sluggish and unequal pupillary responses indicate increased intracranial pressure. This is a classic sign of elevated ICP in pediatric patients with meningitis.

questions.stem: A client with acute pancreatitis is admitted with severe, piercing abdominal pain and an elevated serum amylase. Which additional information is the client most likely to report to the nurse?
options: Abdominal pain decreases when lying supine
Pain lasts an hour and leaves the abdomen tender
Right upper quadrant pain refers to right scapula
Drinks alcohol until intoxicated at least twice weekly
questions.rationale: Pancreatitis pain typically decreases when the client assumes a supine or fetal position due to reduced tension on the pancreas.

questions.stem: A child newly diagnosed with sickle cell anemia (SCA) is being discharged from the hospital. Which information is most important for the nurse to provide the parents prior to discharge?
options: Instructions about how much fluid the child should drink daily
Signs of addiction to opioid pain medications
Information about non-pharmaceutical pain relief measures
Referral for social services for the child and family
questions.rationale: Adequate hydration is the most important preventive measure for sickle cell clients as it helps prevent sickling crises by maintaining blood viscosity.

questions.stem: To auscultate for a carotid bruit, the nurse places the stethoscope at what location?
options: The base of the neck on the right side
The mid-cervical area bilaterally
Just below the angle of the mandible
Over the carotid bifurcation at the level of the thyroid cartilage
questions.rationale: The base of the neck on the right side is the appropriate location to auscultate for carotid bruits, typically at the angle of the mandible.

questions.stem: After receiving report on an inpatient acute care unit, which client should the nurse assess first?
options: The client with an obstruction of the large intestine who is experiencing abdominal distention
The client who had surgery yesterday and is experiencing a paralytic ileus with absent bowel sounds
The client with a small bowel obstruction who has a nasogastric tube that is draining greenish fluid
The client with a bowel obstruction due to a volvulus who is experiencing abdominal rigidity
questions.rationale: Abdominal rigidity with volvulus indicates a surgical emergency with risk of perforation and peritonitis, requiring immediate assessment.

questions.stem: A teenager presents to the emergency department with palpitations after vaping at a party. The client is anxious, fearful, and hyperventilating. The nurse anticipates the client developing which acid base imbalance?
options: Respiratory acidosis
Metabolic alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis
Respiratory alkalosis
questions.rationale: Hyperventilation causes excessive CO2 loss leading to respiratory alkalosis.

questions.stem: A client with dyspnea is being admitted to the medical unit. To best prepare for the client's arrival, the nurse should ensure that the client's bed is in which position?
options: Supine
Supine; feet elevated higher than head
Supine; head elevated higher than feet
Fowlers
questions.rationale: Fowler's position (45-90 degrees) facilitates lung expansion and reduces dyspnea by allowing gravity to assist with breathing.

questions.stem: The nurse is taking the blood pressure measurement of a client with Parkinson's disease. Which information in the client's admission assessment is relevant to the nurse's plan for taking the blood pressure reading? (Select all that apply.)
options: Frequent syncope
Occasional nocturia
Flat affect
Blurred vision
Frequent drooling
questions.rationale: Frequent syncope, flat affect, and blurred vision all relate to Parkinson's disease and can affect accurate blood pressure measurement. Syncope indicates orthostatic hypotension; blurred vision affects client cooperation.

questions.stem: While caring for a client's postoperative dressing, the nurse observes purulent drainage at the wound. Before reporting this finding to the healthcare provider, the nurse should review which of the client's laboratory values?
options: Serum albumin
Culture for sensitive organisms
Serum blood glucose level
Creatinine level
questions.rationale: Culture and sensitivity results guide antibiotic selection and are essential before initiating treatment for wound infection.

questions.stem: A preschool-aged boy is admitted to the pediatric unit following successful resuscitation from a near-drowning incident. While providing care to the child, the nurse begins talking with his preadolescent brother who rescued the child from the swimming pool and initiated resuscitation. The nurse notices the older boy becomes withdrawn when asked about what happened. Which action should the nurse take?
options: Develop a water safety teaching plan for the family
Ask the older brother how he felt during the incident
Tell the older brother that he seems depressed
Commend the older brother for his heroic actions
questions.rationale: Exploring the older brother's feelings about the traumatic incident is the most therapeutic approach to assess his emotional response and provide support.

questions.stem: A male client with cirrhosis has jaundice and pruritus. He tells the nurse that he has been soaking in hot baths at night with no relief of his discomfort. Which action should the nurse take?
options: Encourage the client to use cooler water and apply calamine lotion after soaking
Obtain a PRN prescription for an analgesic that the client can use for symptom relief
Suggest that the client take brief showers and apply oil-based lotion after showering
Explain that the symptoms are caused by liver damage and cannot be relieved
questions.rationale: Cool water reduces pruritus; hot water increases itching. Calamine lotion provides cooling relief for pruritus associated with jaundice.

questions.stem: An older client with a long history of coronary artery disease (CAD), hypertension (HTN), and heart failure (HF) arrives in the Emergency Department (ED) in respiratory distress. The healthcare provider prescribes furosemide IV. Which therapeutic response to furosemide should the nurse expected in the client with acute HF?
options: Increased cardiac contractility
Reduced preload
Relaxed vascular tone
Decreased afterload
questions.rationale: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that reduces fluid volume, thereby decreasing preload and pulmonary congestion in acute heart failure.

questions.stem: Which intervention should the nurse include in the plan of care for a child with tetanus?
options: Encourage coughing and deep breathing
Minimize the amount of stimuli in the room
Reposition from side to side every hour
Open window shades to provide natural light
questions.rationale: Tetanus causes muscle rigidity and spasms triggered by stimuli. Minimizing sensory stimulation reduces the frequency and severity of tetanic spasms.

questions.stem: An adolescent who was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus Type 1 at the age of 9, is admitted to the hospital in diabetic ketoacidosis. Which occurrence is the most likely cause of the ketoacidosis?
options: Ate an extra peanut butter sandwich before gym class
Incorrectly administered too much insulin
Had a cold and ear infection for the past two days
Skipped eating lunch
questions.rationale: Infection and illness increase insulin requirements and can precipitate diabetic ketoacidosis in Type 1 diabetes clients.

questions.stem: A client with a prescription for 'do not resuscitate' (DNR) begins to manifest signs of impending death. After notifying the family of the client's status, what priority action should the nurse implement?
options: The impending signs of death should be documented
The client's status should be conveyed to the chaplain
The client's need for pain medication should be determined
The nurse manager should be updated on the client's status
questions.rationale: Assessing and managing pain is the priority when a client is approaching death, as comfort care becomes the focus of treatment.

questions.stem: Which self care measure is most important for the nurse to include in the plan of care of a client recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus?
options: Self-injection techniques
Blood glucose monitoring
Diabetic diet meal planning
A realistic exercise plan
questions.rationale: Blood glucose monitoring is fundamental for managing diabetes and allows clients to understand how diet, exercise, and medications affect blood glucose levels.

questions.stem: A client who gave birth 48 hours ago has decided to bottle feed the infant. During the assessment, the nurse observes that both breasts are swollen, warm, and tender on palpation. Which instruction should the nurse provide?
options: Apply ice to the breasts for comfort
Wear a loose-fitting bra during the day to prevent nipple irritation
Run warm water over breasts
Express small amounts of milk from the breasts to relieve pressure
questions.rationale: Ice application reduces inflammation, swelling, and pain associated with engorgement in bottle-feeding mothers.

questions.stem: The nurse is preparing a client who had a below-the-knee (BKA) amputation for discharge to home. Which recommendations should the nurse provide this client? (Select all that apply.)
options: Avoid range of motion exercises
Use a residual limb shrinker
Apply alcohol to the stump after bathing
Inspect skin for redness
Wash the stump with soap and water
questions.rationale: Residual limb shrinker helps prepare the limb for prosthesis fitting. Skin inspection prevents complications. Regular washing maintains hygiene. Alcohol is contraindicated as it dries skin. ROM exercises are necessary to prevent contractures.

questions.stem: A toddler presenting with a history of intermittent skin rashes, hives, abdominal pain, and vomiting that occurs after ingesting of milk products arrives to the clinic accompanied by the parents. Which type of testing should the nurse provide education to the toddler's family about?
options: Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE)
Intradermal test
Atopy patch test
Placebo-controlled food challenge
questions.rationale: Serum IgE testing identifies specific food allergies and is appropriate for suspected milk allergy with systemic symptoms.

questions.stem: A client who is scheduled for a bronchoscopy in the morning is anxious and asking the nurse numerous questions about the procedure. In preparing the client for the procedure, which intervention has the highest priority?
options: Allow client to gargle with warm salt water
Administer a sedative to alleviate anxiety
Instruct client to write down the questions
Deny client's request for a midnight snack
questions.rationale: Writing down questions allows the client to express concerns and prepares them for informed consent without unnecessary medication.

questions.stem: The nurse assesses a client one hour after starting a transfusion of packed red blood cells and determines that there are no indications of a transfusion reaction. What instruction should the nurse provide the unlicensed assistive personnel (UAP) who is working with the nurse?
options: Notify the nurse when the transfusion has finished, so further client assessment can be done
Continue to measure the client's vital signs every thirty minutes until the transfusion is complete
Monitor the client carefully for the next three hours and report the onset of a reaction immediately
Since a reaction did not occur, the priority is to maintain client comfort during the transfusion
questions.rationale: Continuous vital sign monitoring every 30 minutes is standard protocol for transfusion monitoring to detect delayed reactions.

questions.stem: The healthcare provider prescribes a sepsis protocol for a client with multi-organ failure caused by a ruptured appendix. Which intervention is most important for the nurse to include in the plan of care?
options: Assess warmth of extremities
Keep head of bed raised 45 degrees
Monitor blood glucose level
Maintain strict intake and output
questions.rationale: Strict intake and output monitoring is critical in sepsis with multi-organ failure to assess organ function and guide fluid replacement therapy.

questions.stem: A client presses the call bell and requests pain medication for a severe headache. To assess the quality of the client's pain, which approach should the nurse use?
options: Ask the client to describe the pain
Observe body language and movement
Identify effective pain relief measures
Provide a numeric pain scale
questions.rationale: Asking the client to describe pain quality (sharp, dull, throbbing, etc.) provides essential information about pain characteristics and potential causes.

questions.stem: A client presents to the labor and delivery unit with a report of leaking fluid that is greenish-brown vaginal discharge. Which action should the nurse take first?
options: Start an intravenous infusion
Administer oxygen via facemask
Perform a vaginal exam
Begin continuous fetal monitoring
questions.rationale: Greenish-brown fluid indicates meconium staining, suggesting fetal distress. Continuous fetal monitoring is the priority to assess fetal status.

questions.stem: A client asks the nurse for information about how to reduce risk factors for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Which information should the nurse provide?
options: Consume a high protein diet
Increase physical activity
Take vitamin supplements
Obtain a prostate-specific antigen blood level test
questions.rationale: Regular physical activity reduces BPH risk factors and improves urinary function through improved circulation and weight management.

questions.stem: The healthcare provider prescribes a fluid challenge of 0.9% sodium chloride 1,000 mL to be infused intravenously over 4 hours. The IV administration set delivers 10gtt/mL. How many gtt/minute should the nurse regulate the infusion? (Round to the nearest whole number)
options: 38 gtt/min
40 gtt/min
42 gtt/min
44 gtt/min
questions.rationale: Calculation: (1000 mL × 10 gtt/mL) ÷ (4 hours × 60 min) = 10,000 ÷ 240 = 41.67 ≈ 42 gtt/min

questions.stem: Following a cardiac catheterization and placement of a stent in the right coronary artery, the nurse administers prasugrel, a platelet inhibitor, to the client. To monitor for adverse effects from the medication, which assessment is most important for the nurse to include in this client's plan of care?
options: Observe color of urine
Measure body temperature
Assess skin turgor
Check for pedal edema
questions.rationale: Prasugrel increases bleeding risk. Dark or hematuria indicates bleeding complications requiring immediate intervention.

questions.stem: A client fell in the bathroom when left unattended by the unlicensed assistive personnel (UAP). Which information should the nurse include in the client's health record?
options: The UAP left the client to assist another client
The last time client was assisted to the bathroom
The unit was understaffed when the client fell
The client fell sustaining a fracture to the left hip
questions.rationale: Objective findings (fracture) and incident details are essential for medical record documentation, not subjective judgments or staffing issues.

questions.stem: The nurse is reviewing the diagnostic tests prescribed for a client with a positive skin test. Which subjective findings reported by the client supports the diagnosis of tuberculosis?
options: Barking cough and vomiting
Mucopurulent cough and night sweats
Dry cough and chest tightness
Chronic cough and fatty stools
questions.rationale: Mucopurulent sputum and night sweats are classic symptoms of active tuberculosis disease.

questions.stem: In assessing a client with type 1 diabetes mellitus, the nurse notes that the client's respirations have changed from 16 breaths/min with a normal depth to 32 breaths/min and deep, and the client become lethargic. Which assessment data should the nurse obtain next?
options: Temperature
Breath sounds
Blood glucose
White blood cell count
questions.rationale: Deep, rapid respirations (Kussmaul breathing) and lethargy indicate diabetic ketoacidosis. Blood glucose assessment is the priority.

questions.stem: A nurse receives report on a client who is four hours post-total abdominal hysterectomy. The previous nurse reports that it was necessary to change the client's perineal pad hourly and that it is again saturated. The previous nurse also reports that the client's urinary output has decreased. Which action should the nurse implement first?
options: Evaluate the skin turgor
Assess for weakness or dizziness
Change the perineal pad
Measure the urinary output
questions.rationale: Excessive bleeding with decreased urinary output suggests hypovolemia. Assessing for signs of shock (weakness, dizziness) is the priority.

questions.stem: The father of a 4-year-old has been battling metastatic lung cancer for the past 2 years. After discussing the remaining options with his healthcare provider, the client requests that all treatment stop and that no heroic measures be taken to save his life. When the client is transferred to the palliative care unit, which action is most important for the nurse working on the palliative care unit to take in facilitating continuity of care?
options: Reassure the client that his child will be allowed to visit
Provide the client written information about end-of-life care
Obtain a detailed report from the nurse transferring the client
Mark the chart with client's request for no heroic measures
questions.rationale: Obtaining comprehensive handoff information ensures continuity of care and understanding of the client's wishes and medical status.

questions.stem: While assessing a client who is admitted with heart failure and pulmonary edema, the nurse identifies dependent peripheral edema, an irregular heart rate, and a persistent cough that produces pink blood-tinged sputum. After initiating continuous telemetry and positioning the client, which intervention should the nurse implement?
options: Obtain sputum sample
Document degree of edema
Initiate hourly urine output measurement
Administer intravenous diuretics
questions.rationale: Pink frothy sputum indicates pulmonary edema. Obtaining a sputum sample helps determine if infection is also present.

questions.stem: A client who is admitted for primary hypothyroidism has early signs of myxedema coma. In assessing the client, in which sequence should the nurse complete these actions? (descending order)
options: 1. Observe breathing patterns, 2. Assess blood pressure, 3. Measure body temperature, 4. Palpate for pedal edema
1. Assess blood pressure, 2. Observe breathing patterns, 3. Measure body temperature, 4. Palpate for pedal edema
1. Observe breathing patterns, 2. Measure body temperature, 3. Assess blood pressure, 4. Palpate for pedal edema
1. Measure body temperature, 2. Observe breathing patterns, 3. Assess blood pressure, 4. Palpate for pedal edema
questions.rationale: In myxedema coma, assessing respiratory status is priority (airway), followed by circulation (blood pressure), then temperature, then other findings.

questions.stem: A client with type 2 diabetes mellitus arrives to the clinic reporting episodes of weakness and palpitations. Which finding should the nurse identify may indicate an emerging situation?
options: Potassium 3.5 mEq/L
Fingertips feel numb
Sodium 135 mEq/L
Cervical spine stiffness
questions.rationale: Numbness in fingertips indicates peripheral neuropathy progressing from poorly controlled diabetes, which is an emerging complication.

questions.stem: An older client is brought to the ED with a sudden onset of confusion that occurred after experiencing a fall at home. The client's daughter, who has power of attorney, has brought the client's prescriptions. Which information should the nurse provide first when reporting to the healthcare provider using SBAR communication?
options: Currently prescribed medications
Client's healthcare power of attorney
Increasing confusion of the client
Fall at home as reason for admission
questions.rationale: SBAR communication starts with the current situation. Acute confusion is the most critical finding requiring immediate attention.

questions.stem: The nurse identifies an electrolyte imbalance, a weight gain of 4.4lbs (2kg) in 24 hours and an elevated central venous pressure for a client with full thickness burns. Which intervention should the nurse implement?
options: Auscultate for irregular heart rate
Review arterial blood gases results
Measure ankle circumference
Document abdominal girth
questions.rationale: Elevated CVP with weight gain indicates fluid overload. Auscultating for irregular heart rate assesses for hyperkalemia effects on cardiac conduction.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a group of clients with the help of a practical nurse (PN). Which nursing actions should the nurse assign to the PN? (Select all that apply.)
options: Administer a dose of insulin per sliding scale for a client with Type 2 DM
Start the second blood transfusion for a client 12 hours following a BKA
Initiate patient controlled analgesia (PCA) pumps for two clients immediately postoperatively
Perform daily surgical dressing change for a client who had an abdominal hysterectomy
Obtain postoperative vital signs for a client one day following unilateral knee arthroplasty
questions.rationale: PNs can administer insulin, perform routine dressing changes, and obtain vital signs. Initating PCA and starting transfusions require RN assessment and judgment.

questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a group of women about osteoporosis and exercise. The nurse should emphasize the need for which type of regular activity?
options: Core strengthening
Aerobic exercise
Weight-bearing exercise
Muscle stretching and toning
questions.rationale: Weight-bearing exercise is most effective for maintaining bone density and preventing osteoporosis by stimulating osteoblast activity.

questions.stem: A client is scheduled for a spiral computed tomography (CT) scan with contrast to evaluate for pulmonary embolism. Which information in the client's history requires follow-up by the nurse?
options: CT scan that was performed 6 months earlier
Metal hip prosthesis was placed 20 years ago
Report of client's sobriety for the last 5 years
Takes metformin for type 2 diabetes mellitus
questions.rationale: Metformin must be withheld before CT with contrast and for 48 hours after due to risk of contrast-induced nephropathy causing lactic acidosis.

questions.stem: A client with type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted for frequent hyperglycemic episodes and a glycosylated hemoglobin (A1C) of 10%. Insulin glargine 10 units subcutaneously once a day at bedtime and a sliding scale of insulin aspart every 6h are prescribed. What actions should the nurse include in this client's plan of care? (Select all that apply.)
options: Do not contaminate the insulin aspart so that it is available for IV use
Review with the client proper foot care and prevention of injury
Teach subcutaneous injection technique, site rotation, and insulin management
Coordinate carbohydrate controlled meals at consistent times and intervals
Mix bedtime dose of insulin glargine with insulin aspart sliding scale dose
Fingerstick glucose assessments every 6h with meals
questions.rationale: These are appropriate diabetes education and management interventions. Insulin aspart is rapid-acting for meals (not IV); insulin types should not be mixed.

questions.stem: The psychiatric nurse is caring for clients on an adolescent unit. Which client requires the nurse's immediate attention?
options: A 14yo client with anorexia nervosa who is refusing to eat the evening snack
A 16yo client diagnosed with major depression who refuses to participate in group
A 17yo client diagnosed with bipolar disorder who is pacing around the lobby
An 18yo client with antisocial behavior who is being yelled at by other clients
questions.rationale: The 18-year-old experiencing conflict with peers requires immediate intervention to prevent escalation and potential violence.

questions.stem: A client at 12 weeks gestation is admitted to the antepartum unit with a diagnosis of hyperemesis gravidarum. Which action is most important for the nurse to implement?
options: Obtain the client's 24-hour dietary recall
Document mucosal membrane status
Schedule a consult with a nutritionist
Initiate prescribed intravenous fluids
questions.rationale: IV fluids address the immediate physiological need for hydration and electrolyte replacement in hyperemesis gravidarum.

questions.stem: A pediatric client is taking the beta-adrenergic blocking agent propranolol. In developing a teaching plan, the nurse should teach the parents to report which sign of overdose?
options: Bradycardia
Tachypnea
Hypertension
Coughing
questions.rationale: Bradycardia is a sign of beta-blocker overdose due to excessive reduction in heart rate and cardiac output.

questions.stem: Prior to obtaining a trapeze bar for a client with limited mobility, which client assessment is most important for the nurse to obtain?
options: Upper body muscle strength
Balance and posture
Risk for disuse syndrome
Pressure sore risk
questions.rationale: The client must have adequate upper body strength to safely use a trapeze bar without risk of injury.

questions.stem: A 3-year-old boy was successfully toilet trained prior to his admission to the hospital for injuries sustained from a fall. His parents are very concerned that the child has regressed in his toileting behaviors. Which information should the nurse provide to the parents?
options: A retraining program will need to be initiated when the child returns home
Diapering will be provided since hospitalization is stressful to preschoolers
A potty chair should be brought from home so he can maintain his toileting skills
Children usually resume their toileting behaviors when they leave the hospital
questions.rationale: Regression during hospitalization is normal stress response in preschoolers and typically resolves after discharge without intervention.

questions.stem: The nurse is managing the care of a client with Cushing's syndrome. Which interventions should the nurse delegate to the unlicensed assistive personnel (UAP)? (Select all that apply.)
options: Report any client complaint of pain or discomfort
Evaluate the client for sleep disturbances
Assess the client for weakness and fatigue
Weigh the client and report any weight gain
Note and report the client's food and liquid intake during meals and snacks
questions.rationale: UAPs can report objective findings like pain, weight changes, and intake. Assessment and evaluation require RN judgment.

questions.stem: A young adult visits the clinic reporting symptoms associated with gastritis. Which information in the client's history is most important for the nurse to address in the teaching plan?
options: Consumes 10 or more drinks of alcohol every weekend
Snacks on foods with very high salt content on a daily basis
Exercises vigorously every evening right before going to bed
Recently became a vegetarian and eats a lot of high fiber foods
questions.rationale: Heavy alcohol consumption is a major risk factor for acute and chronic gastritis and requires priority education for lifestyle modification.

questions.stem: After administering a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), which action should the nurse take to evaluate the effectiveness of the medication?
options: Auscultate for bowel sounds in all quadrants
Ask the client about gastrointestinal pain
Monitor the client's serum electrolyte levels
Measure the client's fluid intake and output
questions.rationale: The primary effect of PPIs is reducing gastric acid production, which relieves GI pain. Asking about pain is the best measure of effectiveness.

questions.stem: When assessing a recently delivered, multigravida client, the nurse finds that her vaginal bleeding is more than expected. Which factor in this client's history is related to this finding?
options: The second stage of labor lasted 10 minutes
She received butorphanol 2mg IVP during labor
She is over 35 years of age
She is a gravida 6, para 5
questions.rationale: Multiparty (gravida 6, para 5) increases risk for postpartum hemorrhage due to decreased uterine muscle tone from overdistention.

questions.stem: When assessing an IV site that is used for fluid replacement and medication administration, the client complains of tenderness when the arm is touched above the site. Which additional assessment finding warrants immediate intervention by the nurse?
options: Client uses the arm cautiously
Red streak tracking the vein
A sluggish blood return
Spot of dried blood at insertion site
questions.rationale: Red streaking indicates thrombophlebitis, a serious complication requiring immediate IV removal and intervention.

questions.stem: An older adult male reporting abdominal pain is admitted to the hospital from a long-term care facility. It has been 7 days since his last bowel movement, his abdomen is distended, and he just vomited 150mL of dark brown emesis. In what order should the nurse implement these interventions? (Highest to lowest priority)
options: 1. Elevate the head of the bed, 2. Complete focused assessment, 3. Send emesis sample to the lab, 4. Offer PRN pain medication
1. Complete focused assessment, 2. Elevate the head of the bed, 3. Send emesis sample to the lab, 4. Offer PRN pain medication
1. Send emesis sample to the lab, 2. Elevate the head of the bed, 3. Complete focused assessment, 4. Offer PRN pain medication
1. Elevate the head of the bed, 2. Send emesis sample to the lab, 3. Offer PRN pain medication, 4. Complete focused assessment
questions.rationale: Priority: Assess (determining if emergent), position, diagnostic sample, comfort measures.

questions.stem: When taking a health history, which information collected by the nurse correlates most directly to a diagnosis of chronic peripheral arterial insufficiency?
options: History of intermittent claudication
A positive Brodie-Trendelenburg test
Ankle ulceration and edema
A serum cholesterol level of 250mg/dl (6.47mmol/L)
questions.rationale: Intermittent claudication (pain with exercise relieved by rest) is the hallmark symptom of peripheral arterial insufficiency.

questions.stem: The nurse is providing discharge teaching to the parents of a 13 month old child who underwent repair for an atrial septal defect. The healthcare provider prescribes aspirin and an antibiotic for the first 6 months postoperatively to prevent infective endocarditis (IE). What information is most important for the nurse discuss with the parents about the child's recovery and prevention of IE?
options: Refer the mother to the healthcare provider to discuss infective endocarditis
Brush the child's teeth every day and ensure the child receives regular dental followup
Give the child acetaminophen for pain or fever and visit the surgeon for follow-up
Monitor the child for regular bowel movements and urine output that exceeds intake
questions.rationale: Dental hygiene and regular dental care are critical to prevent bacteremia and IE in post-cardiac surgery patients.

questions.stem: An unlicensed assistive personnel (UAP) is assigned to ambulate a client with influenza who has droplet precautions implemented. The UAP requests a change in assignment, stating the reason of having not been fitted yet for a N95 respirator mask. Which action should the nurse take?
options: Send the UAP to be fitted for a particulate filter mask immediately so she can provide care to this client
Instruct the UAP that a standard face mask is sufficient for the provision of care for the assigned client
Before changing assignments, determine which staff members have fitted particulate filter masks
Advise the UAP to wear a standard face mask to take vital signs, and then get fitted for a filter mask before providing personal care
questions.rationale: Influenza requires droplet precautions. A standard surgical mask is appropriate for influenza; N95 respirator is for airborne precautions.

questions.stem: The nurse implements a tertiary prevention program for type 2 diabetes in a rural health clinic. Which outcome indicates that the program was effective?
options: Only 30% of clients did not attend self-management education sessions
More than 50% of at-risk clients were diagnosed early in their disease process
Clients who developed disease complications promptly received rehabilitation
Average client scores improved on specific risk factor knowledge tests
questions.rationale: Tertiary prevention focuses on managing existing disease and complications. Prompt rehabilitation for complications demonstrates effectiveness.

questions.stem: The nurse identifies several nursing problems for client who is immobile and who has been experiencing fecal incontinence and diarrhea for several days. The client's spouse is the primary caregiver. In planning care, which problem has the highest priority?
options: Impaired bed mobility
Caregiver role strain
Fluid volume deficit
Bowel incontinence
questions.rationale: Bowel incontinence must be managed first to prevent skin breakdown, infection, and allow for other interventions.

questions.stem: The nurse is feeding an older adult who was admitted with aspiration pneumonia. The client is weak and begins coughing while attempting to drink through a straw. Which intervention should the nurse implement?
options: Teach coughing and deep breathing exercises
Assess the client's oral cavity for ulcerations
Request thick nectar liquids for the client
Monitor the client when using a straw for liquids
questions.rationale: Teaching coughing and deep breathing helps clear aspiration and improves clearance of secretions in pneumonia.

questions.stem: An adult client is admitted to the emergency department after falling from the ladder. While waiting to have a computed tomography (CT) scan, the client requests something for a severe headache. When the nurse offers a prescribed dose of acetaminophen, the client asks for something stronger. Which intervention should the nurse implement?
options: Review client's history for use of illicit drugs
Explain the reason for using only non-narcotics
Assess client's pupils for their reaction to light
Request that the CT scan be done immediately
questions.rationale: Non-narcotics must be used before CT scan to avoid masking neurological changes from potential head injury. Narcotics could obscure assessment findings.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a client who has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and chest pain related to a recent fall. What nursing intervention requires the greatest caution when caring for a client with COPD?
options: Monitoring telemetry and cardiac rhythm
Assisting client to cough and deep breath
Administering narcotics for pain relief
Increasing the client's fluid intake
questions.rationale: Narcotics depress respiratory drive, which is dangerous in COPD clients who depend on hypoxia to stimulate breathing.

questions.stem: The nurse is providing care for a client with schizophrenia who receives haloperidol decanoate 75mg IM every 4 weeks. The client begins developing a puckering and smacking of the lips and facial grimacing. Which intervention should the nurse implement?
options: Monitor lying, sitting, and standing blood pressures
Provide coaching in relaxation techniques
Complete abnormal involuntary movement scale (AIMS)
Discontinue all medications immediately
questions.rationale: Lip smacking and facial grimacing indicate tardive dyskinesia, an extrapyramidal side effect. AIMS assessment documents severity of involuntary movements.

questions.stem: Prolonged exposure to high concentrations of supplemental oxygen over several days can cause which pathophysiological effect?
options: Disrupted surfactant production
Metabolic acidosis
Aphasia and memory loss
Deep sleep or coma
questions.rationale: High oxygen concentrations can disrupt surfactant production and cause oxygen toxicity, leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.stem: A client who recently received a prescription for ramelteon to treat sleep deprivation reports experiencing several side effects since taking the drug. Which side effect should the nurse report to the healthcare provider?
options: A change in the sleep-wake cycle
Mild sedation
Dizziness reported after initial dose
Somnambulism
questions.rationale: Somnambulism (sleepwalking) is a serious side effect of ramelteon requiring provider notification and possible discontinuation.

questions.stem: The nurse instructs a client in use of a incentive spirometer. The client performs a return demonstration as seen in the video. Which action should the nurse take in response to the return demonstration?
options: Auscultate the client's lungs for adventitious sounds
Encourage the client to practice until successful
Emphasize the need to inhale slowly into the spirometer
Remind the client to cough after using the spirometer
questions.rationale: After incentive spirometer use, coughing helps mobilize secretions that may have been loosened by deep breathing.

questions.stem: A client tells the nurse about working out with a personal trainer and swimming three times a week in an effort to lose weight and sleep better. The client states that it still is taking hours to fall asleep at night. Which action should the nurse implement?
options: Advise the client that lifestyle changes often take several weeks to be effective
Encourage the client to exercise everyday to eliminate bedtime wakefulness
Ask the client for a description of the exercise schedule that is being followed
Determine the amount of weight the client has lost since increasing activity
questions.rationale: Asking for exercise schedule details helps assess if timing is appropriate (exercise close to bedtime can delay sleep onset).

questions.stem: The nurse is developing an educational program for older clients who are being discharged with new antihypertensive medications. The nurse should ensure that the education materials include which characteristics? (Select all that apply.)
options: Uses common words with few syllables
Printed using a 12-point type font
Uses pictures to help illustrate complex ideas
Contains a list with definitions of unfamiliar terms
Written at a twelfth-grade reading level
questions.rationale: Older adults benefit from simple language, visual aids, and definitions. 8-10 point font is too small; 5th-6th grade reading level is appropriate.

questions.stem: The nurse is providing care for a client with severe peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The client reports a history of rest ischemia, with leg pain that occurs during the night. Which action should the nurse take in response to this finding?
options: Elevate the legs to assess for color changes
Provide a heating pad for PRN use
Offer cold packs when the pain occurs
Suggest dangling the legs when pain occurs
questions.rationale: Dangling the legs improves blood flow by gravity in PAD with rest ischemia, providing pain relief.

questions.stem: The nurse assess a client being treated for Herpes zoster (shingles). Which assessments should the nurse include when evaluating the effectiveness of the treatment? (Select all that apply.)
options: Functional ability
Skin integrity
Pain scale
Bowel sounds
Heart sounds
questions.rationale: Functional ability and skin integrity directly reflect treatment effectiveness for herpes zoster. Bowel and heart sounds are not relevant.

questions.stem: A heparin infusion is prescribed for a client who weighs 220 pounds. After administering a bolus dose of 80 units/kg, the nurse calculates the infusion rate for the heparin solution at 18 units/kg/hr. The available solution is Heparin Sodium 25,000 units in 5% Dextrose injection 250mL. The nurse should program the infusion pump to deliver how many mL/hour?
options: 16 mL/hour
18 mL/hour
20 mL/hour
22 mL/hour
questions.rationale: Calculation: 220 lbs ÷ 2.2 = 100 kg; 100 kg × 18 units/kg = 1,800 units/hr; (1,800 ÷ 25,000) × 250 = 18 mL/hr

questions.stem: When providing client care the nurse identifies a problem and develops a related clinical question. Next, the nurse intends to gather evidence so that the decision-making process in response to the problem and clinical question is evidence-based. When gathering evidence, which consideration is most important?
options: Past experience with similar problems
Relevance to the situation
Related personal values
Frequency that the problem occurs
questions.rationale: Evidence-based practice requires that gathered evidence be directly relevant to the specific clinical problem and situation.

questions.stem: A client diagnosed with calcium kidney stones has a history of gout. A new prescription for aluminum hydroxide is scheduled to begin at 0730. Which client medication should the nurse bring to the healthcare provider's attention?
options: Esinapril
Allopurinol
Furosemide
Aspirin, low dose
questions.rationale: Allopurinol (uricosuric agent) reduces uric acid. Aluminum hydroxide may reduce absorption of allopurinol, requiring dosing adjustments.

questions.stem: A client with urge incontinence was treated with onabotuilinumtoxinA injections and is now experiencing urinary retention. Which action should the nurse include in the client's plan of care?
options: Provide a bedside commode for immediate use in the client's room
Teach the client techniques for performing intermittent catheterization
Explain the need to limit intake of oral fluids to reduce client discomfort
Remind the client to practice pelvic floor (Kegel) exercises regularly
questions.rationale: Pelvic floor exercises strengthen muscles to overcome retention caused by botox treatment of the detrusor muscle.

questions.stem: After a spider bite on the lower extremity, a client is admitted for treatment of an infection that is spreading up the leg. Which admission assessment findings should the nurse report to the healthcare provider? (Select all that apply.)
options: Location of the initial IV site
Red blood cell count (RBC)
Swollen lymph nodes in the groin
White blood cell count (WBC)
Core body temperature
questions.rationale: Lymphadenopathy, elevated WBC, and fever indicate spreading infection and systemic response requiring provider notification.

questions.stem: The home care nurse visits a client who has cancer. The client reports having a good appetite but experiencing nausea when smelling food cooking. Which action should the nurse implement?
options: Encourage family members to cook meals outdoors and bring the cooked food inside
Assess the client's mucous membranes and report the findings to the healthcare provider
Advise the client to replace cooked foods with a variety of different nutritional supplements
Instruct the client to take an antiemetic before every meal to prevent excessive vomiting
questions.rationale: Cooking odors trigger nausea. Preparing food outside and bringing cooked food in eliminates the trigger without medication.

questions.stem: The nurse is wearing personal protective equipment (PPE) while caring for a client. When exiting the room, which PPE should be removed first?
options: Gloves
Mask
Eyewear
Gown
questions.rationale: Gloves are removed first as they are most contaminated. Removing gloves first prevents contaminating other PPE.

questions.stem: An older male client, who is a retired chef, is hospitalized with a diabetic ulcer on his foot. His daughter tells the nurse that her father has become increasingly obsessed with the way his food is prepared in the hospital. The nurse's response should be based on what information?
options: The client probably has an organic brain disease and will likely have Alzheimer's disease within a few years
The family needs a social worker to talk to them about how to handle their father when he becomes annoying
The daughter is under stress and should be encouraged to think about happier times
If the client was compulsive about food when he was younger, the aging process can magnify this
questions.rationale: Personality traits and behaviors often become more pronounced with aging. A former chef's focus on food preparation is consistent with lifelong values.

questions.stem: A client is receiving enoxaparin 30mg subcutaneously twice a day. In assessing for adverse effects of the medication, which serum laboratory value is most important for the nurse to monitor?
options: Glucose
Calcium
Platelet count
White blood cell count
questions.rationale: Enoxaparin (LMWH) can cause heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), requiring regular platelet count monitoring.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a 24-month-old toddler who has sensory sensitivity, difficulty engaging in social interactions, and has not yet spoken two-word phrases. Which assessment should the nurse administer?
options: The Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (M-CHAT)
Psychology Systems Questionnaire (PHQ-2)
Behavioral Style Questionnaire (BSQ)
The Ages and Stages Questionnaire (ASQ)
questions.rationale: M-CHAT is specifically designed for autism screening in toddlers aged 16-30 months with these presenting concerns.

questions.stem: Prior to surgery, written consent must be obtained. Which is the nurse's legal responsibility with regard to obtaining written consent?
options: Explain the surgical procedure to the client and ask the client to sign the consent form
Ask the client or a family member to sign the surgical consent form
Determine that the surgical consent form has been signed and is included in the client's record
Validate the client's understanding of the surgical procedure to be conducted
questions.rationale: The nurse's legal responsibility is to ensure the consent form is properly signed and documented. The provider obtains informed consent.

questions.stem: A client with hyperthyroidism is admitted to the postoperative unit after a subtotal thyroidectomy. Which of the client's serum laboratory values requires intervention by the nurse?
options: T3-uptake at 50%
Glucose 150 mg/dL
Total calcium 5.0 mg/dL
Thyroxine 12 mcg/dL
questions.rationale: Calcium 5.0 mg/dL indicates hypocalcemia, likely from hypoparathyroidism post-thyroidectomy, requiring immediate intervention.

questions.stem: A client in the third trimester of pregnancy reports that she feels some 'lumpy places' in her breasts and that her nipples sometimes leak a yellowish fluid. She has an appointment with her healthcare provider in two weeks. What action should the nurse take?
options: Tell the client to begin nipple stimulation to prepare for breast feeding
Reschedule the client's prenatal appointment for the following day
Explain that this normal secretion can be assessed at the next visit
Recommend that the client start wearing a supportive brassiere
questions.rationale: These are normal findings of third trimester pregnancy (colostrum production and fibrocystic changes) that can be assessed at routine visit.

questions.stem: While the nurse is assessing an older client's fall risk, the client reports living at home alone and never falling. Which action should the nurse take?
options: Inform the client that falls occur more often in the hospital than at home
Record a minimal risk for falls, documenting the client's statement
Continue to obtain client data needed to complete the fall risk survey
Place the client on a high fall risk protocol because of advanced age
questions.rationale: Fall risk assessment requires comprehensive data collection, not relying on client self-report alone or age alone.

questions.stem: The nurse is providing education to a client who experiences recurrent levels of moderate anxiety to situations and perceived stress. In addition to information about prescribed medication and administration, which instruction should the nurse include in the teaching?
options: Find outlets for more social interaction
Practice using muscle relaxation techniques
Center attention on positive upbeat music
Think about reasons the episodes occur
questions.rationale: Muscle relaxation techniques provide concrete coping mechanisms for managing anxiety symptoms.

questions.stem: A young woman with multiple sclerosis just received several immunizations in preparation for moving into a college dormitory. Two days later, she reports to the nurse that she is experiencing increasing fatigue and visual problems. What teaching should the nurse provide?
options: Plans to move into the dormitory need to be postponed for at least a semester
These are common side effects of the vaccines and will resolve in a few days
Immunizations can trigger a relapse of the disease, so get plenty of extra rest
These early signs of an infection may require medical treatment with antibiotics
questions.rationale: Immunizations can trigger MS relapses due to immune stimulation. Rest and monitoring are appropriate with possible medications.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a preterm newborn with nasal flaring, grunting, and sternal retractions. After administering surfactant, which assessment is most important for the nurse to monitor?
options: Arterial blood gases
Breath sounds
Oxygen saturation
Respiratory rate
questions.rationale: ABGs directly measure oxygenation and ventilation effectiveness of surfactant therapy in respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.stem: An S3 heart sound is auscultated in a client in her third trimester of pregnancy. What intervention should the nurse take?
options: Prepare the client for an echocardiogram
Document in the client's record
Notify the healthcare provider
Limit the client's fluids
questions.rationale: S3 is a normal finding in third trimester pregnancy due to increased blood volume. Documentation is appropriate without further intervention.

questions.stem: A young male client is admitted to rehabilitation following a right above-knee amputation (AKA) for a severe traumatic injury. He is in the commons room and anxiously calls out to the nurse, stating that his 'right foot is aching'. The nurse offers reassurance and support. Which additional intervention is most important for the nurse to implement?
options: Encourage discussion of feelings about the loss of his limb
Administer a prescription for gabapentin, a neuroleptic agent
Teach the client how to wrap the stump with an elastic bandage
Offer to assist the client to a quieter location so he can relax
questions.rationale: Phantom pain is common post-amputation. Addressing emotional adjustment and grief related to limb loss is foundational to pain management.

questions.stem: A combination multi-drug cocktail is being considered for an asymptomatic HIV-infected client with a CD4 cell count of 500. Which nursing assessment of the client is most crucial in determining whether therapy should be initiated?
options: Willing to comply with complex drug schedules
Maintains an adequate social support system
Qualifies for a prescription assistance program
States various side effects of retroviral agents
questions.rationale: Adherence is critical for HIV treatment success. Complex regimens require high compliance to prevent resistance.

questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a seated client who is experiencing a tonic-clonic seizure. Which actions should the nurse implement? (Select all that apply.)
options: Loosen restrictive clothing
Insert a bite block
Ease the client to the floor
Note the duration of the seizure
Restrain the client
questions.rationale: Loosen clothing to prevent injury, ease to floor safely, and document duration. Never insert objects or restrain during seizure.

questions.stem: On admission to the Emergency Department, a female client who was diagnosed with bipolar disorder 3 years ago reports that this morning she took a handful of medications and left a suicide note for her family. Which information is most important for the nurse to obtain?
options: Which family member has the client's suicide note
What drugs the client used for the suicide attempt
When the client last took drugs for bipolar disorder
Whether the client over attempted suicide in the past
questions.rationale: Determining which medications were taken and when is critical for medical management and toxicology assessment.

questions.stem: The nurse has completed the diet teaching of a client who is being discharged following treatment of a leg wound. A high protein diet is encouraged to promote wound healing. Which lunch choice by the client indicates that the teaching was effective?
options: A tuna fish sandwich with chips and ice cream
A salad with three kinds of lettuce and fruit
A peanut butter sandwich with soda and cookies
Vegetable soup, crackers, and milk
questions.rationale: Tuna is high protein (wound healing), providing necessary nutrients even though chips and ice cream aren't optimal.

questions.stem: The nurse has received funding to design a health promotion project for African-American women who are at risk for developing breast cancer. Which resource is most important in designing this program?
options: A listing of African-American women who live in the community
Morbidity data for breast cancer in women of all races
Participation of community leaders in planning the program
Technical assistance to produce a video on breast self-examination
questions.rationale: Community participation ensures culturally appropriate, relevant, and effective program design and implementation.

questions.stem: A new nurse preparing to irrigate an intravenous catheter is attaching a 24-gauge needle. Which action should the charge nurse implement?
options: Suggest the nurse use a 20-gauge needle
Instruct the nurse to remove the needle
Direct the nurse to change the IV tubing
Prompt the nurse to apply povidone to the site
questions.rationale: 24-gauge is too small for IV irrigation, increasing risk of hemolysis. 20-gauge or larger is appropriate.

questions.stem: After reviewing the Braden Scale findings of residents at a long-term facility, the charge nurse should tell the unlicensed assistive personnel (UAP) to prioritize skin care for which client?
options: A poorly nourished client who requires liquid supplements
An older adult who is unable to communicate elimination needs
A woman with osteoporosis who is unable to bear weight
An older man whose sheets are damp each time he is turned
questions.rationale: Constant moisture from incontinence significantly increases pressure ulcer risk and requires priority interventions.

questions.stem: An increased number of elderly persons are electing to undergo a new surgical procedure which cures glaucoma. Which effect is the nurse likely to note as a result of this increase in glaucoma surgeries?
options: Decreased prevalence of glaucoma in the population
Increased incidence of glaucoma in the population
Decreased morbidity in the elderly population
Increased mortality in the elderly population
questions.rationale: Curing existing cases (those surgically treated) decreases the prevalence of glaucoma in the population.

questions.stem: An adult female client tells the nurse that though she is afraid her abusive boyfriend might one day kill her, she keeps hoping that he will change. Which action should the nurse take first?
options: Explore client's readiness to discuss the situation
Determine the frequency and type of client's abuse
Report the finding to the police department
Discuss treatment options for abusive partners
questions.rationale: Exploring readiness is the foundation for any intervention in domestic violence situations. Readiness determines timing and type of interventions.

questions.stem: A client's morning assessment includes bounding peripheral pulses, weight gain of 2 pounds (0.91 kg), pitting ankle edema, and moist crackles bilaterally. Which intervention is most important for the nurse to include in this client's plan of care?
options: Maintain accurate intake and output
Administer prescribed diuretic
Weigh client every morning
Restrict daily fluid intake to 1500mL
questions.rationale: These signs indicate fluid overload requiring diuretic therapy to reduce preload and pulmonary congestion.

questions.stem: The nurse is evaluating the chest drainage system of a client with a chest tube inserted to treat a left hemothorax. Which finding requires intervention by the nurse?
options: Rise and fall of water level with respiration
Continuous bubbling in the water-seal chamber
Total fluid level in water-seal chamber unchanged
An average collection of 50 mL/hr drainage
questions.rationale: Continuous bubbling indicates an air leak, requiring immediate inspection of connections and the chest tube system.

questions.stem: A client in the emergency center demonstrates rapid speech, flight of ideas, and reports sleeping only three hours during the past 48 hours. Based on these findings, it is most important for the nurse to review the laboratory value for which medication?
options: Lorazepam
Fluoxetine
Divalproex
Olanzapine
questions.rationale: Rapid speech, flight of ideas, and decreased sleep suggest manic/hypomanic symptoms. Divalproex (mood stabilizer) levels need monitoring.

questions.stem: A client with bacterial meningitis is receiving phenytoin. Which assessment finding indicates to the nurse that the client is experiencing a therapeutic response?
options: Absence of seizures
Normal electroencephalogram after drug administration
Decreased muscle rigidity
Normalized body temperature
questions.rationale: Normal EEG after phenytoin administration indicates therapeutic seizure control and therapeutic response.

questions.stem: The nurse is demonstrating correct transfer procedures to the unlicensed assistive personnel (UAP) working on a rehabilitation unit. The UAP asks the nurse how to safely move a physically disabled client from the wheelchair to a bed. Which action should the nurse recommend?
options: Apply a gait belt around the client's waist once a standing position has been assumed
Place the client's locked wheelchair on the client's strong side next to the bed
Pull the client into position by reaching from the opposite side of the bed
Hold the client at arm's length while transferring to better distribute the body weight
questions.rationale: Placing the locked wheelchair on the strong side allows the client to transfer using the stronger side and minimizes fall risk.

questions.stem: The nurse is auscultating a client's lung sounds. Which description should the nurse use to document this sound?
options: Stridor
Low pitched or coarse crackles
High pitched or fine crackles
High pitched wheeze
questions.rationale: High-pitched fine crackles indicate pulmonary edema or interstitial process and indicate fine crackles on documentation.

questions.stem: A client taking clopidogrel reports the onset of diarrhea. Which nursing action should the nurse implement first?
options: Observe the appearance of the stool
Assess the elasticity of the client's skin
Review the client's laboratory values
Auscultate the client's bowel sounds
questions.rationale: Observing stool appearance helps distinguish between normal diarrhea and GI bleeding (dark/tarry stools), a potential clopidogrel side effect.

questions.stem: A female client with a history of heart failure (HF) arrives at the clinic after what she describes as a very long trip. Following the initial physical assessment and chart review, which priority action should the nurse implement?
options: Administer the prescribed diuretic
Give a potassium supplement
Reteach medication regimen
Auscultate lung and heart sounds
questions.rationale: After a long trip (likely prolonged immobility), a HF client with clinical signs needs diuretic therapy to prevent decompensation.

questions.stem: The nurse is preparing a client for discharge who was hospitalized with an acute flare of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) symptoms. Which instruction is most important for the nurse to include?
options: Use a walker when weakness occurs
Take prescribed cortisone accurately
Decrease daily intake of sodium in diet
Avoid extreme environmental temperatures
questions.rationale: SLE clients are photosensitive and sensitive to temperature extremes. Avoiding extreme temperatures prevents SLE flares.

questions.stem: A nurse working on an Endocrine Unit should see which client first?
options: An older client with Addison's disease whose current blood sugar level is 62 mg/dL
A client taking corticosteroids who has become disoriented in the last two hours
An adolescent male with type 1 diabetes who is arguing about his insulin dose
An adult with a blood sugar of 384 mg/dL and a urine output of 350mL in the last hour
questions.rationale: Acute disorientation indicates a medical emergency (hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia crisis, or adrenal crisis) requiring immediate assessment.

questions.stem: The nurse assesses a client who has bilateral total knee replacements (TKR) four hours ago. The nurse notes that the dressing on the client's right knee is saturated with serosanguineous drainage. What action should the nurse implement?
options: Monitor the client's current WBC
Withhold next scheduled dose of low molecular weight heparin
Confirm that the continuous passive motion device is intact
Determine if the wound drainage device is functioning correctly
questions.rationale: Excessive sanguineous drainage 4 hours post-op requires assessment of proper wound drainage device function before other interventions.

questions.stem: The healthcare provider prescribes cephalexin 125mg/5mL oral suspension for a client who weighs 77 pounds. The recommended safe dose 25mg/kg/24 hours in 4 divided doses. Based on the client's weight, how many mL should the nurse administer?
options: 8 mL
9 mL
10 mL
11 mL

questions.stem: A middle-aged client, admitted to a critical care unit several weeks ago because of serious injuries sustained in a motor vehicle accident, is currently in stable condition. Based on the client's age and recent life-threatening crisis, which intervention should the nurse implement?
options: Encourage the client to reflect on personal goals and priorities
Allow long periods of uninterrupted rest in order to reduce fatigue
Discuss the cause of the accident with the client and his family
Provide a routine schedule of activities to facilitate trust
questions.rationale: Life-threatening experiences often trigger existential reflection. Encouraging goal and priority reflection supports psychological recovery.

questions.stem: A young adult male who is being seen at the employee health care clinic for an annual assessment tells the nurse that his mother was diagnosed with schizophrenia when she was his age and that life with a schizophrenic mother was difficult indeed. Which response is best for the nurse to provide?
options: Encourage the client to seek genetic counseling to determine his risk for mental illness
Inform the client that his mother's schizophrenia has affected his psychological development
Tell the client that mental illness has a familial predisposition so he should see a psychiatrist
Ask the client if he is worried about becoming schizophrenic at the age his mother was diagnosed
questions.rationale: Asking about his concerns acknowledges his worry, opens communication, and assesses his current mental health status.

questions.stem: Which laboratory finding for an adult client is most critical for the nurse to report to the healthcare provider?
options: Serum sodium 142mEq/L
Serum potassium 3.9mEq/L
Serum glucose 62 mg/dL
Blood urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL
questions.rationale: Glucose of 62 mg/dL indicates hypoglycemia, which can cause seizures, loss of consciousness, and requires immediate intervention.

questions.stem: When conducting diet teaching for a client who was diagnosed with a myocardial infarction, which snack foods should the nurse encourage the client to eat? (Select all that apply.)
options: Fresh vegetables with mayonnaise dip
Fresh turkey slices and berries
Chicken bouillon soup and toast
Soda crackers and peanut butter
Raw unsalted almonds and apples
questions.rationale: Turkey is lean protein, berries are low sodium, bouillon is low fat, almonds are unsalted and healthy. Mayo and peanut butter are high fat.

questions.stem: A client with a lower respiratory tract infection receives a prescription for ciprofloxacin 500mg PO every 12 hours. When the client requests an afternoon snack, which dietary choice should the nurse provide?
options: Cinnamon applesauce
Vanilla-flavored yogurt
Calcium-fortified juice
Low-fat chocolate milk
questions.rationale: Ciprofloxacin binds with calcium, reducing absorption. Applesauce doesn't contain calcium and won't interfere with absorption.

questions.stem: When admitting a client with a diagnosis of transient ischemic attack (TIA), which intervention is most important for the nurse to include in this client's plan of care?
options: Assess bilateral breath sounds
Review client's daily medications
Initiate neurological monitoring every 2 hours
Palpate suprapubic region for urinary retention
questions.rationale: Neurological monitoring detects signs of progressing stroke, which is the main complication risk with TIA.

questions.stem: An older client's daughter calls the home health nurse and reports that her mother has become forgetful and is very confused at night. The daughter stated that her mother's behavior changed suddenly a few days ago and is now getting worse. Which actions should the nurse take? (Select all that apply.)
options: Encourage increased intake of high protein foods
Instruct the daughter to check her mother's temperature
Review the client's current food and medication allergies
Ask if the mother is experiencing any pain with urination
Determine if the mother has recently experienced a fall
questions.rationale: Acute confusion suggests infection (check temp), UTI (dysuria), or malnutrition. Protein helps cognitive function. Allergies may be unrelated to acute onset.

questions.stem: The nurse who works in labor and delivery is reassigned to the cardiac care unit for the day because of a low census in labor and delivery. Which assignment is best for the charge nurse to give this nurse?
options: Assist cardiac nurses with their assignments
Monitor the central telemetry
Perform the admission of a new client
Transfer a client to another unit
questions.rationale: Assisting with assignments allows the nurse to function safely while building cardiac experience, avoiding independent care of unfamiliar clients.

questions.stem: A client with Type 1 diabetes mellitus and a large draining ulcer of the right foot is admitted with a suspected Staphylococcus aureus infection. Which interventions should the nurse implement? (Select all that apply.)
options: Monitor the client's white blood cell count
Explain the purpose of a low bacteria diet
Send wound drainage for culture and sensitivity
Institute contact precautions for staff and visitors
Use standard precautions and wear a mask
questions.rationale: WBC indicates infection severity; culture guides antibiotics; contact precautions prevent transmission. Low bacteria diet and masking alone are not indicated.

questions.stem: The nurse is managing 4 clients in the intensive care unit who are mechanically ventilated. After performing a quick visual assessment, the nurse should prioritize care for the client who is exhibiting which finding?
options: An audible voice when client is trying to communicate
High pressure alarm sounds when client is coughing
Restrained and restless with a low volume alarm sounding
Diminished breath sounds in the right posterior base
questions.rationale: Restlessness with low volume alarm indicates possible disconnection or tube obstruction, an emergency requiring immediate intervention.

questions.stem: A male client tells the nurse that he is concerned that he may have a stomach ulcer, because he is experiencing heartburn and a dull gnawing pain that is relieved when he eats. Which is the best response by the nurse?
options: Instruct the client that these mild symptoms can generally be controlled with changes in his diet
Advise the client that he needs to seek immediate medical evaluation and treatment of these symptoms
Encourage the client to obtain a complete physical exam, since these symptoms are consistent with an ulcer
Assure the client that his symptoms may only reflect reflux, since ulcer pain is not relieved with food
questions.rationale: The symptoms described are consistent with peptic ulcer disease but could also be reflux. Professional evaluation is needed for diagnosis.

questions.stem: The nurse is evaluating the diet teaching of a client with hypertension. What dinner selection indicates that the client understands the dietary recommendations for hypertension?
options: Grilled steak, baked potato with sour cream, green beans, coffee, and raisin cream pie
Baked pork chops, applesauce, corn on the cob, 1% milk, and key-lime pie
Tomato soup, grilled cheese sandwich, pickles, skim milk, and lemon meringue pie
Beef stir fry, fried rice, egg drop soup, diet soda, and pumpkin pie
questions.rationale: Baked lean pork, fruits/vegetables, low-fat milk, and moderate dessert show understanding of low-sodium, low-fat hypertension diet.

questions.stem: A client is admitted with a diagnosis of urolithiasis. Which finding is most important for the nurse to report to the healthcare provider?
options: Volume of each voiding is more than 300mL
Serum potassium that is elevated
Relief of flank pain that radiated into the groin
Hematuria that is beginning to turn pink
questions.rationale: Increasing hematuria (darker color) indicates worsening kidney damage or ureteral trauma requiring immediate intervention.

questions.stem: Three days after initiating parenteral fluids for a newborn with a ventricular septal defect (VSD), the nurse assesses an increase in heart rate and blood pressure. Which intervention is most important for the nurse to implement?
options: View the graph of daily weights
Restrict intake of oral fluids
Assess bilateral lung sounds
Decrease IV flow rate
questions.rationale: Increased heart rate and BP in VSD with parenteral fluids suggests fluid overload. Restricting intake and assessing for pulmonary edema are priorities.

questions.stem: During an admission assessment, a client reports currently using heroin. Which information is most important for the nurse to consider in the plan of care?
options: History of suicide attempts
Feelings of disorientation
Undiagnosed social anxiety symptoms (SAD)
Family history of schizophrenia
questions.rationale: Heroin users have elevated suicide risk; understanding past attempts informs safety planning and monitoring.

questions.stem: The healthcare provider prescribes penicillin G benzathine 2,400,000 units intramuscularly for a client who has a postoperative wound infection. The prefilled syringe is labeled, penicillin G benzathine 1,200,000 units/2mL. How many mL should the nurse administer to this client?
options: 2 mL
3 mL
4 mL
5 mL
questions.rationale: Calculation: (2,400,000 units ÷ 1,200,000 units) × 2 mL = 4 mL

questions.stem: A client who experienced a cerebrovascular accident (CVA) is aphasic and has left sided paralysis. Which nurse should be responsible for coordinating the progression of this client's care?
options: Nurse case manager
Adult nurse practitioner
Neurology unit supervisor
Risk management nurse
questions.rationale: Adult nurse practitioners coordinate interdisciplinary care for complex medical conditions like post-CVA rehabilitation.

questions.stem: A client who is admitted with complications related to hypopituitarism is diaphoretic and hypotensive. Which assessment finding warrants immediate intervention by the nurse?
options: Lethargy
Elevated temperature
Increased appetite
Muscle cramps
questions.rationale: Lethargy with hypotension and diaphoresis indicates possible adrenal crisis, a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention.

questions.stem: A client with postpartum depression, who is admitted to the behavioral health unit, refuses to leave her room or eat meals. In addition to maintaining physical safety, which short-term goal should the nurse include in the plan of care?
options: Sleeps at least 6 hours per night
Consumes 3 meals and 1500 mL of fluid per day
Engages in one client to client interaction daily
Attends one group activity per day
questions.rationale: Engaging in one group activity addresses social isolation while being achievable for a depressed client refusing meals/leaving room.

questions.stem: A 7-year old is admitted to the hospital with persistent vomiting, and a nasogastric tube attached to low intermittent suction is applied. Which finding is most important for the nurse to report to the healthcare provider?
options: Shift intake of 640mL IV fluids plus 30mL PO ice chips
Serum pH of 7.45
Gastric output of 100 mL in the last 8 hours
Serum potassium of 3.0 mg/dL
questions.rationale: Potassium of 3.0 indicates severe hypokalemia from gastric fluid losses, causing cardiac dysrhythmia risk requiring immediate replacement.

questions.stem: A male client approaches the nurse with an angry expression on his face and raises his voice, saying 'My roommate is the most selfish, self-centered, angry person I have ever met and if he loses his temper one more time with me, I am going to punch him out!' The nurse recognizes that the client is using which defense mechanism?
options: Splitting
Projection
Rationalization
Denial
questions.rationale: Projection is attributing one's own unacceptable traits to others. The client is projecting his own anger onto his roommate.

questions.stem: The nurse is teaching the client about home care after surgery for an ileal conduit placement. When reviewing the information, which statement should the nurse recognize as needing additional education?
options: Report presence of mucus in the urine
Empty pouch when it is half full
Look at the stoma when replacing appliance
Anticipate shrinking of the stoma
questions.rationale: Pouches should be emptied when one-third to one-half full to prevent leakage and skin irritation. Waiting until half full is not optimal timing.

questions.stem: A nurse who is working in the emergency department triage area is presented with four clients at the same time. The client presenting with which symptoms requires the most immediate intervention by the nurse?
options: One inch bleeding laceration on the chin of crying 5 year old
Low grade fever, headache and malaise for the past 72 hours
Chest discomfort one hour after consuming a large, spicy meal
Unable to bear weight on the left foot, with swelling and bruising
questions.rationale: Chest discomfort could indicate acute coronary syndrome, a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate assessment.

questions.stem: When the nurse enters the room of a male client who was admitted for a fractured femur, his cardiac monitor displays a normal sinus rhythm, but he has no spontaneous respirations and his carotid pulse is not palpable. Which intervention should the nurse implement?
options: Analyze the cardiac rhythm in another lead
Obtain a 12-lead electrocardiogram
Observe for swelling at the fracture site
Begin chest compressions at 100/minute
questions.rationale: No pulse and no spontaneous respirations indicate cardiac arrest. CPR must be initiated immediately at 100-120 compressions/minute.

questions.stem: The nurse identifies the presence of clear fluid on the surgical dressing of a client who just returned to the unit following lumbar spinal surgery. Which action should the nurse implement immediately?
options: Change the dressing using a compression bandage
Test the fluid on the dressing for glucose
Document the findings in the electronic medical record
Mark the drainage area with a pen and continue to monitor
questions.rationale: Clear fluid from spinal surgery could be cerebrospinal fluid. Testing for glucose indicates CSF (CSF contains glucose; serum does not).

questions.stem: After administering a 12 ounce can of nutritional supplement, 3 teaspoons of medication, and 120 mL of water, the nurse should document the client's fluid intake as how many mL?
options: 475 mL
495 mL
515 mL
535 mL
questions.rationale: Calculation: 12 oz = 360 mL (1 oz = 30 mL); 3 tsp medication = 15 mL; 120 mL water; Total = 360 + 15 + 120 = 495 mL

questions.stem: The nurse observes a client prepare a meal in the kitchen of a rehabilitation facility prior to discharge. Which behaviors indicate the client understands how to maintain balance safely? (Select all that apply.)
options: Brings a heavy can close to body before lifting
Leans forward to pull on a pan from a high shelf
Locks knees while preparing food on the counter
Bends from the waist to pick trash off the floor
Widens stance while working near the sink
questions.rationale: Bringing items close and widening stance improve balance. Leaning forward, locking knees, and bending waist impair balance and cause injury.

questions.stem: A client with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) starts a new prescription for etanercept subcutaneously once weekly. The nurse should emphasize the importance of reporting which problem to the healthcare provider?
options: Joint stiffness
Persistent fever
Headache
Increased hunger and thirst
questions.rationale: Etanercept (TNF inhibitor) increases infection risk. Persistent fever indicates possible infection requiring immediate provider notification.

questions.stem: A client with multiple burn injuries is being treated in the burn trauma unit just hours after the injuries occurred. The healthcare provider instructs the nurse to avoid auto contamination when performing dressing changes. Which intervention is most important for the nurse to implement?
options: Dress each wound separately
Assign equipment to this one client
Utilize reverse isolation protocol
Use gown, mask, and gloves with dressing changes
questions.rationale: PPE prevents transfer of microorganisms from nurse to open burn wounds, preventing autocontamination.

questions.stem: A client with chronic kidney disease has an arteriovenous fistula in the left forearm. Which observation by the nurse indicates that the fistula is patent?
options: Assessment of a bruit on the left forearm
Auscultation of a thrill on the left forearm
The left radial pulse is 2+ bounding
Palpation of a smooth, cordlike vessel
questions.rationale: A thrill (palpable vibration) indicates adequate blood flow through the fistula, confirming patency.

questions.stem: A client is recovering in the critical care unit following a cardiac catheterization. IV nitroglycerin and heparin are infusing. The client is sedated but responds to verbal instructions. After changing positions, the client complains of pain at the right groin insertion site. What action should the nurse implement?
options: Check femoral site for hematoma formation
Stimulate the client to take deep breaths
Evaluate the integrity of the IV insertion site
Assess distal lower extremity capillary refill
questions.rationale: Groin pain after position change in cardiac cath client on heparin suggests femoral artery bleeding/hematoma formation requiring immediate assessment.
